title: What is the Flavor Triangle?
text: Cocktail flavor comes from balancing three main components: base spirit, sour/bitter ingredients, and sweet ingredients.

title: Base Spirit
text: The base spirit is the foundation of a cocktail, providing most of the alcohol content and shaping the overall flavor of the drink. It gives the cocktail its strength, structure, and primary taste, whether that's the smokiness of whiskey, the brightness of gin, or the tropical sweetness of rum. Common base spirits include vodka, gin, rum, tequila, whiskey, and brandy. Each spirit offers a different character.

title: Sour / Bitter
text: Sour and bitter ingredients are essential for balancing the sweetness and alcohol in a cocktail. Sour elements like lime, lemon, and grapefruit juice add brightness and acidity that refresh the palate. Bitter components, such as tonic water, Angostura bitters, or bitter liqueurs like Campari, bring complexity and depth. These flavors often define a drink's edge or bite and prevent it from becoming too sweet.

title: Sweet
text: Sweet ingredients add body, smoothness, and balance to cocktails by softening strong or sour elements. Sweetness can come from simple syrup, honey, agave, fruit juices, liqueurs, or even creamy ingredients like coconut milk. These components round out the flavor of the drink and make it more approachable.

title: Margarita
text: Base spirit: 2 oz Tequila Sour/Bitter: 1 oz Lime juice Sweet: 0.75 oz Triple sec or agave syrup

title: Paloma
text: Base spirit: 2 oz Tequila Sour/Bitter: 2 oz Grapefruit juice, 0.5 oz Lime juice Sweet: 0.5 oz Simple syrup

title: Negroni
text: Base spirit: 1 oz Gin Sour/Bitter: 1 oz Campari Sweet: 1 oz Sweet Vermouth

title: Whiskey Sour
text: Base spirit: 2 oz Whiskey Sour/Bitter: 0.75 oz Lemon juice Sweet: 0.75 oz Simple syrup
